Background: - Dataset procured from the National Transportation Safety Board (NSTB). - Contains records of aircraft crashes in the U.S. from Jan 1, 1980, to Dec 31, 2022. - Originally comprised 89,134 rows and 38 columns, refined to 20 columns for focused analysis. ::: ::: nonincremental **Value** Enhance understanding of aviation safety and factors contributing to aircraft crashes. - Personalize insights based on diverse experiences with air travel. ::: ## Questions Proposed ::: incremental 1. What are the aircraft crashes' locations, timings, and consequences? 2. ``` ::: ::: Here, VMC stands for `Visual Meteorological Conditions` and IMC stands for `Instrument Meteorological Conditions`. ::: ## Radial Bar-Plot ::: nonincremental Radial Bar Plot - Total Crashes Radial Bar Plot - Total Crashes ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](presentation_files/figure-html/radial_plot_crashes-1.png){fig-align='center'} ::: ::: Radial Bar Plot - Total Injuries ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](presentation_files/figure-html/radial_plot_injuries-1.png){fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: ## Conclusion ::: incremental - Annual crash occurrences remain notable, but a declining trend is observed over the decades from 1980 to 2022. - The consistent decrease in the number of crashes indicates an improvement in aviation safety standards and practices. - Strict regulations within the aviation industry have contributed to the reduction in both crash frequency and fatalities. - The decline in fatalities over time underscores the effectiveness of safety measures and protocols implemented in the aviation sector. ::: ## Conclusion ::: incremental - The overall trend suggests a positive shift towards a safer and more efficient mode of transportation. - As fatalities and crashes continue to decrease, air travel becomes an increasingly secure and rapid means of global transportation. - The ongoing improvement in aviation safety reflects the industry's commitment to providing a reliable and secure travel experience. - The collective progress in safety measures signifies a broader positive trajectory for the aviation sector, fostering confidence in air travel for passengers worldwide. ::: ## Problems Faced and Future Scope ::: nonincremental :::
